Patch Set 21:

(10 comments)
Hi Matt, I've left some initial queries in the headers. I figure I can take a closer look at the implementation once we have consensus on the header discussions.

Must we encode them at this stage? Can we instead pass back a pointer to an array of a concrete type (`struct pldm_descriptor`?) rather than an opaque buffer? I prefer we keep the marshalling in the message codec APIs and avoid spreading it around if possible.
OK, I'll have a look at using the structures from https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/libpldm/+/75733 .
I've done that now.
Can we please switch these throughout to negative errnos as discussed in comments on other patches?

Can do. I think any -ve errno would be translated into a generic `PLDM_ERROR`. 

Note that `firmware_data()`/`verify()`/`activate()` will still return specific status codes since they have meaning, so there'll be a bit of variation in the API there.
Yeah, that's fine I think, so long as the documentation calls it out.
Done
Maybe it's worth adding a `PLDM_FD_DEFINE_P()` macro in the same sense as `PLDM_MSG_DEFINE_P()`?
Can do. It would be nice to have a macro working with C too, unsure if there's any way to cast there in a way that that clang-tidy will be happy with (without the placement new).

Yeah, defining something for C is fine. I hadn't done it as I didn't want to expose anything in the public headers that didn't have an immediate use. The clang-tidy warning is specific to `reinterpret_cast<>()`, C-style casts in C code should be fine.
In my use case I'm putting the backing storage and `struct pldm_fd*` into an separate external struct, so will think about the best way to do that.

I prefer we don't propagate the `pldm_requester_rc_t` type either, and again defer to negative errnos. Do you mind fixing it throughout? Hopefully it doesn't cause too much grief in the implementation.
Negative errno makes sense here, `pldm_requester_rc_t` was a bit arbitrary, I'll change it.
Done
Should we be using TIDs instead?
Probably? That said, I suspect most users would end up translating back to MCTP EID themselves (as pldmd firmware update does)

Yeah, I just prefer to keep non-PLDM concepts out of the APIs as much as we can. The transport APIs do provide transport-specific mapping functions. Maybe it's worth some thought about whether we should separate those out so there's less impact from the meson `transport` build switch?
Done
Same query here.
Done
What's the motivation for the `libpldm-` prefix in the basename of the file given it's already namespaced under the `libpldm/` directory?
I think I'd missed there was already a directory, have moved it.
Maybe try adding them to the `dependencies` argument to the `compiler.sizeof()` call?
I tried a few things there, but didn't manage to get it to work. Will have a look further.
Hi Matt, I'm happy to merge this aside from a few nitpicks noted inline.
Whitespace seems a bit funky here.
And here
More funky whitespace 😊
The described parameter doesn't exist in the function declaration. Should this be deleted?
Drop this as well?
Funky whitespace again
Probably worth adding `LIBPLDM_CC_NONNULL` annotations for the static functions. It's an optimisation, but it also provides some compiler hints on misuse.

Bit of a nit, but I've generally been requesting that variables are declared up-front and assigned later, rather than mixing code and declarations. This tends to match kernel-style (though this isn't required by `Documentation/process/coding-style.rst` from a brief search).

Do you mind addressing this throughout, unless there are good reasons otherwise (`const` objects)?

prefer `LIBPLDM_CC_UNUSED`?

If so, there are a few other instances where this can be applied below.
